[b]Short and sweet version if you don't feel like reading through.[/b]

I was reluctant to purchase this game after reading reviews and other commentary around the internet. Ultimately, I do recommend this game, [b]with some caution[/b]. Continue reading for more information.

[hr][/hr]

[h1][b][u]The Good[/u][/b][/h1]

This game has loads of potential. You will see this game is tagged as Early Access and it's currently in beta. This is not immediately evident inside the game. The menus and graphics are gorgeous for this style of game. The music is well matched. The crafting and cooking systems are pretty basic, but there is huge potential to expand items and recipes. There are several things you can cook and craft in the game currently, but I feel like you could do plenty more with minor changes to the current items. For example, you can use 4 bundles of wheat to craft a bag of flour and then use 4 bags of flour make a loaf of bread. Or 3 to make a croissant. You can eat both the bread and the croissant, but that's it. I would like to see a recipe where you can use a loaf of bread and add fish or some other meat and create a sandwich for example. Everything appears to be single tiered at the moment, when there is clearly room for multiple tiers.

The map itself is beautifully done and the different climates offer great variety of looks suited to the climate.

[h1][b][u]The In-between[/u][/b][/h1]

I started with my own server that I played on privately for about 8 hours. While it was fun, it got old fairly quickly as there was no one to interact with. While I plan to continue my private server for testing and playing, I've opted to try the US-WEST Uuvana 1 server to get some human contact.

Once you begin to walk around, you will notice there aren't many people around. One thing this game appears to be lacking is NPCs. There are plenty of items to interact with, but with the lack of population (due to a mixture of the game's infancy and some toxicity within the community caused by griefers), you would expect more NPC to interact with. This is not the case. While it isn't horrible, it can feel very lonely at times. Especially since the map is large. It may not seem like it, but without a well thought out plan and some assistance from a Dinghy or boat, it can take several minutes to trek from one end of the map to the other. While you can technically swim from shore to shore, you use massive amounts of energy doing this and you would die without feeding yourself multiple food items.

The different climates are fantastic however, I do find that in it's current state of beta, there isn't a huge variety in food, wildlife (not really any variety at all here besides the fish) and I would like to see the tents and houses take on a different look based on the climate area you choose to station.

[h1][b][u]The Bad[/u][/b][/h1]

There seems to be a LOT of anger towards the developers due to the constant wipes, bugs and lack of moderation for the most part with cheaters and griefers. While I personally understand this game is truly in it's infancy, others are not as understanding. This comes with the territory when you charge for a game that isn't "done". We currently live in a world where we apparently choose to pay to alpha and beta test, and while that's not necessarily a bad thing on it's own, it does set a precedence that allows some developers or develop studios to establish a bit of an ego. While it's easy to say "This game is in Early Access or beta, there will be bugs", it's an entirely different beast to charge money for it and then just say "Sorry, not sorry".

Uuvana Studios skirts a fine line in this regard. They do like to remind players every chance they get that this is indeed not a finished product and while you did pay for it, you aren't actually entitled to anything other than access to the game. I've seen people complain, rage and beg in their Discord because their entire collection was wiped due to an update. Uuvana Studios offers no solution to this aside from a reminder you are playing an unfinished game on an unfinished server. This is understandable of course however, it is absolutely bad customer service and should be recognized as such. I don't know of a solution to this issue but I do recognize it as that thin line mentioned above.

Running a private server was relatively simple. A little [i]too[/i] simple I dare say. I mention this because there are very few things you can change about the game's configuration. I expect that to change at some point, but I don't think it's on the radar to make any drastic changes to this. I would like the ability to configure all aspects of the game such as pricing, recipe configurations, damage numbers, drop quantities etc. This is something currently lacking (or at least I couldn't find any way to configure those things).

[h1][b][u]Conclusion[/u][/b][/h1]

I do believe this game can be great. There are so many aspects that feel like they're just scratching the surface here. There's potential for numerous levels of crafting and cooking. The PvP aspect of the game adds something unique to an otherwise entirely different genre, but could use some tweaking. I'm excited to see where this game is going to and especially excited for the possibility of a Workshop full of mods.

Like so many people before me have already mentioned, this game is essentially what would happen if Animal Crossing and Rust had a baby.

At first glance, you'd look at Longvinter and think "Oh, they released Animal Crossing for PC?", because from an audio/visual standpoint, it resembles Animal Crossing, almost entirely. That being said, once you actually hop in and start playing the game, you'll quickly notice that this game differs from AC quite a bit.

Just like at the start of Animal Crossing: New Horizons, your primary objective is to set up camp, in the form of a tent. The tent can be acquired by purchasing it from a vending machine, located in one of the many outposts spread out across the world. Just follow the shoreline and you'll be sure to find one. However, in order to purchase your first tent, you'll need to earn some cash.

So what does one have to do to earn a quick buck, you ask?
There are a few different ways to go about this in Longvinter. Collecting plants, fishing, looting the various landmarks spread around the world for items, and then selling all the aforementioned things at the vending machines back at the outposts. Even PvP can be profitable, but you most likely won't be doing that as soon as you join your first server.

When you've gathered enough money and purchased your first tent, it's now time to find a nice spot to call home. This is where Longvinter starts differing quite a bit from Animal Crossing, and leaning more into the Rust-side of things.

You see, as I mentioned above, PvP is a very real thing in Longvinter, so being strategic about the placement of your tent is going to be fairly important, since you'll be competing for resources with all the other players that live around you.

Once your tent is set up in a nice spot, you'll want to either buy or find a fireplace and a workbench to place inside your tent, as well as a few containers to store your hard-earned loot in. These things can all be found both in vending machines, and in lootable containers at the various landmarks around the world.

The workbench is arguably your most important piece of furniture/technology here, as not only does it allow you to craft a multitude of items, such as weaponry or furniture, but it also allows you to upgrade your tent to a house by collecting 100 pieces of wood. This is especially useful, since your tent will by default be automatically removed after a set amount of time.

The fireplace (along with campfires) will allow you to cook food and regenerate energy, which is also used as health in Longvinter.

So now that you've got your house set up, what's next?
Well, you'll probably want to set up some planter boxes outside your house to grow various plants, such as berry bushes or flowers. And it would be silly to just let your neighbors walk onto your land and allow them to steal your crops, so you may as well build some fencing around your house to keep them out.

But then, what's to stop your neighbors from just breaking down your fence and stealing your precious flowers anyway? Time to start building some automated sentry turrets and place those bad boys all around your garden. That should show those thieving neighbors that you're not messing around. Actually, while you're at it, you've probably got a couple of weapons and some ammo laying around from all the looting you've been doing. Why not put those to use and show the neighbors who is the boss in this neighborhood. Guns solve everything in Longvinter.

Jokes aside, as of this review, the game is still freshly in Early Access since less than a month back, and there's not a whole lot to do in the game at this point in time, but Longvinter already has a ton of potential to hit on multiple different audiences, whether you're coming from a PvP/Survival-background or a more casual Sim/Farming/Building-background, there will be something for everyone in this game.

So far, I haven't run into a single bug or crash in my short time playing the game, and most of the interactions that I've had with other players have been a quick wave before heading in opposite directions. The developers seem incredibly keen to listen to their community, and although they appear to already have a vision for what they want their game to become, it looks like they are very interested in making something that their playerbase actually wants to play, plus they post frequently about what's currently being worked on.

I look forward to seeing what's to come for Longvinter.
